title: 107_s2774
content: The "APHIS Function Transfer Act" allows for the transfer of certain agricultural inspection functions from the Department of Agriculture. The "APHIS Function Transfer Act" allows for the transfer of certain agricultural inspection functions from the Department of Agriculture. Definitions in this section include various laws such as the Act of August 31, 1922, the Federal Seed Act, the Plant Protection Act, the Animal Health Protection Act, the Endangered Species Act of 1973, the Lacey Act Amendments of 1981, and the Virus-Serum-Toxin Act. The "APHIS Function Transfer Act" transfers agricultural inspection functions from the Department of Agriculture to the Secretary of Homeland Security. The transferred authority must be exercised in accordance with regulations issued by the Secretary of Agriculture. Coordination between the two departments is required for rulemaking. The Secretary of Agriculture shall coordinate with the Secretary of Homeland Security for regulations at ports of entry or similar locations. The Secretary of Homeland Security may issue directives for effective use of personnel. Transfer Agreement between the two departments must be established promptly after the Act's enactment. After the Act's enactment, the Secretaries of Agriculture and Homeland Security must agree on transferring functions, including supervision of training and fund transfers. The agreement can be revised jointly as needed. The Secretaries of Agriculture and Homeland Security may revise the agreement as necessary, allowing the Secretary of Homeland Security to perform functions related to the protection of domestic livestock and plants not transferred under subsection (b), and the Secretary of Agriculture to utilize Department of Agriculture employees. Agriculture may utilize Department of Homeland Security employees to carry out authorities delegated to the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service for the protection of domestic livestock and plants. The Secretary of Agriculture shall periodically transfer funds collected as fees to the Secretary of Homeland Security for activities related to the fees collected. The fees collected under sections 2508 and 2509 of the Food, Agriculture, Conservation, and Trade Act of 1990 are limited in proportion to the costs incurred by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The Secretary of Agriculture is required to transfer not more than 3,200 full-time equivalent positions to the Secretary of Homeland Security. Additionally, there is a provision for the protection of inspection animals. The Department of Agriculture is required to transfer positions to the Secretary of Homeland Security. There is a provision for the protection of inspection animals. The Department of Agriculture is required to transfer positions to the Secretary of Homeland Security, with a provision for the protection of inspection animals. SEC. 501 defines the Secretary Concerned. The term 'Secretary concerned' is defined in SEC. 501 as the Secretary of Agriculture for animals used in official inspections by the Department of Agriculture, and the Secretary of Homeland Security for animals used in official inspections by the Department of Homeland Security. Amendments are made to include the Department of Homeland Security in relevant sections. Amendments are made to include the Department of Homeland Security in relevant sections by inserting "or the Secretary of Homeland Security" after "Secretary of Agriculture" and replacing "Secretary" with "Secretary concerned". Section 503 of the Agricultural Risk Protection Act of 2000 is also amended by changing "501" to "502". The Plum Island Animal Disease Center of the Department of Agriculture will be transferred to the Secretary of Homeland Security, including assets and liabilities. The Secretary of Agriculture will retain access to the Center for research and diagnostic activities through an agreement with the Secretary of Homeland Security.
